title: 107_hr873
content:
The Act titled "AMT Rate Reduction Act of 2001" reduces marginal income tax rates for individuals. The "AMT Rate Reduction Act of 2001" reduces marginal income tax rates for individuals, specifically for married individuals filing joint returns and surviving spouses for the year 2002. The tax rates based on taxable income are as follows:
- Not over $12,000: 14% of taxable income
- Over $12,000 but not over $45,200: $1,680 plus 15% of the excess over $12,000
- Over $45,200 but not over $109,250: $6,660 plus 27% of the excess over $45,200
- Over $109,250 but not over $166,450: $23,953.50 plus 30% of the excess over $109,250
- Over $166,450 but not over $297,300: $41,113.50 plus 35% of the excess over $166,450
- Over $297,300: $86,911 plus 38% of the excess The tax for heads of households is determined based on taxable income, with a rate of $86,911 plus 38% of the excess over $297,300. Tax rates based on taxable income are as follows:
- Not over $10,000: 14% of taxable income
- Over $10,000 but not over $36,250: $1,400 plus 15% of the excess over $10,000
- Over $36,250 but not over $93,600: $5,337.50 plus 27% of the excess over $36,250
- Over $93,600 but not over $151,600: $20,822 plus 30% of the excess over $93,600
- Over $151,600 but not over $297,300: $38,222 plus 35% of the excess over $151,600
- Over $297,300: $89,217 plus 38% of the excess Tax rates for unmarried individuals (excluding surviving spouses and heads of households) are determined based on taxable income. The tax rate is $89,217 plus 38% of the excess over $297,300. Tax rates for unmarried individuals are based on taxable income. For income not over $6,000, the tax rate is 14%. For income over $6,000 but not over $27,050, the tax rate is $840 plus 15% of the excess over $6,000. For income over $27,050 but not over $65,550, the tax rate is $3,997.50 plus 27% of the excess over $27,050. For income over $65,550 but not over $136,750, the tax rate is $14,362.50 plus 30% of the excess over $65,550. For income over $136,750 but not over $297,300, the tax rate is $35,752.50 plus 35% of the excess. For income over $297,300, the tax rate is $91,945 plus 38% of the excess. For married individuals filing separate returns, a tax is imposed on taxable income based on a specific table. For married individuals filing separate returns, a tax is imposed on taxable income based on a specific table. The tax rates are as follows:
- Not over $6,000: 14% of taxable income
- Over $6,000 but not over $22,600: $840, plus 15% of the excess over $6,000
- Over $22,600 but not over $54,625: $3,330, plus 27% of the excess over $22,600
- Over $54,625 but not over $83,225: $11,976.75, plus 30% of the excess over $54,625
- Over $83,225 but not over $148,650: $20,556.75, plus 35% of the excess over $83,225
- Over $148,650: $43,455.50, plus 38% of the excess The tax rates for married individuals filing separate returns are as follows: 14% on income not over $6,000, 15% on income over $6,000 but not over $22,600, 27% on income over $22,600 but not over $54,625, 30% on income over $54,625 but not over $83,225, 35% on income over $83,225 but not over $148,650, and 38% on income over $148,650. There is a phase-in of rate reductions for taxable years beginning after 2002. The tax rates for married individuals filing separate returns are reduced by 1 percentage point in taxable years beginning in 2004 and an additional 1 percentage point in 2006 for the 27 and 35 percent rates. For the 30 and 38 percent rates, there is a reduction of 1 percentage point in each taxable year after 2002 and before 2006, and an additional 2 percentage points in taxable years starting in 2006. The Secretary will adjust the tables to implement these reductions. Inflation adjustments will apply in determining rates for 2002. The tax rates for married individuals filing separate returns are reduced in taxable years starting in 2004 and 2006. There will be adjustments to the tables to implement these reductions, with inflation adjustments applying for 2002. Additionally, there are specific rules for certain brackets in calendar years 2002 through 2006, with no adjustments to the dollar amounts at which the first and second rate brackets begin. In later calendar years, adjustments to tax tables will be made by substituting '2005' for '2000'. Various provisions are amended by replacing '1992' with '2000' in different sections. Various sections of the tax code are referenced, including Section 68(b)(2)(B), Section 132(f)(6)(A)(ii), Section 135(b)(2)(B)(ii), and others. The tax code is amended in various sections, including changes to percentages and dates. For example, Section 25A and Section 42 are amended, as well as Section 1 and Section 531. The tax code is amended in multiple sections, changing percentages such as 39.6 percent to 33 percent, 28 percent to 15 percent, and 31 percent to 25 percent. The Secretary of the Treasury has the authority to adjust these percentages as needed. The amendments made by this subsection will coordinate percentages with those in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The effective dates for these changes are after December 31, 2001, except for specific withholding provisions which apply to amounts paid after the same date. SEC. 3. REDUCTION IN ALTERNATIVE MINIMUM TAX RATES FOR INDIVIDUALS. The amendment reduces the tentative minimum tax rate for individuals to 25 percent of the taxable excess, with a phase-in of a reduced rate of 27 percent for taxable excess exceeding $175,000. The tentative minimum tax rate for individuals is reduced to 27 percent for taxable years beginning in 2002 or 2003, and 26 percent for taxable years beginning in 2004 or 2005. These amendments apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2001.
